introduction: directdemocracy est une application mobile permettant à tous et partout de proposer des référendums et voter. Elle présente toutes les garanties d'un logiciel de vote électronique moderne. Les citoyens s'assermentent les uns les autres dans un réseau de confiance. Les gouvernements ne pourront plus faire taire ni ignorer la voix de leur peuple.

about-text: DirectDemocracy Association est une association à but non lucratif basée en Suisse qui promeut l'application de vote électronique directdemocracy pour imposer la démocratie directe partout dans le monde.
motivation:
Notre motivation: L’humanité fait face à des menaces de plus en plus inquiétantes : réchauffement climatique, extinctions de masse, guerres, menace nucléaire, pauvreté, famines, etc. Malheureusement, les systèmes de gouvernance actuels sont généralement impuissants à résoudre ces problèmes. Ils sont souvent corrompus par des intérêts économiques et trop lents. Nous sommes convaincus que seule la démocratie peut aider l’humanité à éviter, tant que possible, ces catastrophes. Cependant, la démocratie est actuellement en recul dans le monde. Pour la faire progresser, nous développons une nouvelle technologie qui permet un système de gouvernance mondial basé sur la démocratie directe. Conçue autour d’une application mobile de vote électronique, open-source et décentralisée, elle permet à chacun de proposer des référendums municipaux, régionaux, nationaux et mondials et à tous de voter de manière anonyme, vérifiable et impossible à censurer. Avec cet outil, l’humanité peut décider librement, rapidement et de manière incontestable sur les sujets qui la concernent. Les gouvernements devront alors alors choisir leur camp : soit appliquer les décisions démocratiques ou s’exposer à un soulèvement populaire.

Le but de notre association est de promouvoir cet outil démocratique qui vise à inverser la tendance actuelle de recul démocratique et à appliquer la démocratie directe partout dans le monde pour le plus grand bien de l’humanité.

a1:
Réponse : oui.

directdemocracy est développé par une organisation à but non-lucratif qui ne poursuit pas d'intérêts commerciaux. Nos développements et notre infrastructure sont financés par des fondations et des dons d'utilisateurs. Tout le logiciels utilisé dans directdemocracy est gratuit et open-source. C'est une garantie que directdemocracy restera gratuit pour toujours.
q2: Je ne veux pas publier mon nom, ma photo d'identité et/ou mon adresse, puis-je tout de même devenir citoyen ?
a2:
Réponse: peut-être, mais ce n'est pas recommandé.

Après s'être inscrit comme citoyen, votre nom, photo d'identité et adresse sont publiées, en particulier sur les webservices des notaires. Peut-être avez vous de bonnes raisons pour ne pas vouloir publier ces informations, comme le soucis de protéger votre vie privée. Cependant, directdemocracy repose sur un réseau de confiance pour assurer que vous existez réellement en tant que citoyen et ces informations sont nécessaires aux autres participants du réseau de confiance pour vous reconnaître comme étant un citoyen réel. Il est toujours possible d'utiliser un nom d'emprunt, une photo d'identité floue et/ou placer votre adresse à la mairie de votre village ou ville. Dans ce cas, quand vous demanderez à vous voisins de vous assermenter, vous devrez leur expliquer pourquoi vous n'avez pas publié vos informations réelles. Si vos explications sont convaincantes, ils seront peut-être d'accord de vous assermenter. Cependant, si vous n'avez pas de bonnes raisons, des juges pourraient décider de désapprouver votre carte de citoyen, s'ils ont un doute, vous empêchant ainsi de voter ou signer.
q3: Ma réputation est 0 et je ne peux pas voter ou signer, que dois-je faire ?
a3:
Réponse: faites-vous assermenter pas vos voisins.

If you reputation is 0, this means that the judges of directdemocracy do not consider you as a citizen. This is probably due to the fact that you just registered and were not yet endorsed by others. To fix it, you should meet your neighbors and ask them to endorse you. Explain them about directdemocracy and propose them to install the app if not already done. Once they have installed the app, they should register as a citizen before they can endorse you. This should take a couple of minutes. Then, they will be able to endorse you from the app. In return, it is fair to also endorse them back. Each time you get endorsed by a neighbor, you should see your reputation increase. Whenever your reputation reaches 0.5, you will be considered as a citizen and be able to vote at referendums and sign petitions. You will need approximately 5 or 6 endorsements from neighbors to become a citizen. It is better to ask close neighbors because the endorsements of people living far away from you have less impact on your reputation.
q4: Quelle est la différence entre un référendum et une pétition ?
a4:
Short answer: referendums are anonymous answers to questions, petitions are public commitments.

In directdemocracy, there are several differences between a petition and a referendum. Both are proposals aiming a specific area, on which the citizens can express themselves. However, unlike a referendum, a petition has no question and no answers. Instead, the citizen shall simply sign the petition if they agree with it. Signing a petition is not anonymous, everyone can see the list of citizens who signed a petition. On the other hand a referendum is anonymous. Nobody can see the answer of a citizen to the question of a referendum. It is only possible to see how many selected each answer.
q5: Est-ce que quelqu'un peut voir ma réponse à la question d'un référendum ?
a5:
Short answer: no.

Your answer to the question of a referendum is fully anonymous and it should not be possible for anyone to see it. Basically, the ballot that you are casting is anonymous and was blindly signed by the directdemocracy app after verifying that you are allowed to vote and before sending it to the polling station. The whole system was designed to guarantee all the necessary properties of a modern voting systems, including anti-tampering and anonymity.
q6: Est-il possible de tricher, par exemple, voter ou signer plusieurs fois ?
a6:
Short answer: no.

The web of trust guarantees that each citizen has only one vote for each referendum, one signature for each petition.
q7: J'ai changé d'avis concernant un référendum, puis-je changer mon vote ?
a7:
Short answer: yes, until the deadline.

During a referendum campaign, the debate should bring regularly new arguments allowing citizens to make their choice on what they will vote. Even if they already voted, a citizen may change their mind and re-vote differently if the deadline of the referendum has not yet passed. Only their last vote will be taken into account. This allows citizens to change their mind during a referendum campaign, which we believe is fair and good for democracy.
q8: Quel est le but de directdemocracy dans les pays qui ont déjà une démocratie directe, comme la Suisse ?
a8:
Short answer: a faster, cheaper democratic process.

In countries already ruled by a direct democracy, like Switzerland, the referendum is a very long process which requires gathering a large number of signatures, verifying these signatures, passing a number of administrative checks, setting a voting calendar, etc. before the citizens can actually vote on the referendum. The whole process typically lasts more than one year. That makes emergency decisions impossible to take by the people. For example during the COVID-19 pandemic, emergency decisions were taken by the government regardless of the people's agreement. Democratic votations regarding these decisions came afterwards, which is sounded wrong. With directdemocracy, it is extremely fast to run a referendum and get results. The whole process could be reduced to one month or less in case of emergency.

Launching a referendum in a country ruled by a direct democracy like Switzerland is also a costly process mainly because you have to collect many paper signatures. Thus it is not easy for a citizen to launch a referendum. Once the signatures are collected, verified and you passed the administrative checks, you will have to launch a campaign with adverising posters, press releases, interviews, etc. Although the voting campaign costs are about the same with directdemocracy, there is no need for a signature collection campaign. Therefore it saves a lot of costs and makes the first steps of launching a referendum much cheaper and more accessible to anyone. This constitutes a good point for democracy.
q9: Quelle est la différence principale entre directdemocracy et d'autres systèmes de vote électronique ?
a9:
Short answer: citizens registration is fully decentralized.

In addition to featuring all the standard properties of e-voting systems (anonymous, tamper-proof, verifiable, open-source, etc.), directdemocracy provides the missing building block of a fully decentralized voting system: the ability to issue citizen cards in a decentralized manner. This is an essential component to quickly enforce direct democracy in countries where governments refuse it, like in France for example where President Macron refused to introduce the RIC on April 25th, 2019 as a response to the Yellow Vest Protest.

Issuing trustable citizen cards allows the results of referendums and petition to be trustable as well. Therefore they can weight signficantly on polical decisions taken by governments. So, in addition to be a e-voting system, directdemocracy also features the ability to enforce direct democracy even in countries where it is not accepted by the local authorities.
q10: Qu'est ce que le réseau de confiance ?
a10:
Short answer: a proof of the existance of unique citizens.

The web of trust is a decentralized system which is based on the fact that everyone knows everyone through others. If you know 1000 people and each of them know 500 different people, who know 500 different people and so on. After seven iterations or so, you would be in touch with the whole population of the world. If you can personnaly assess that your neighbors are unique citizens and if all the citizens can do the same, then, you are building a web of trust.

This is what you will have to do in directdemocracy with endorsements. In order to get recognized as a citizen, you should get endorsed by and endorse others citizens.
q11: Comment puis-je proposer un référendum (ou une pétition) ?
a11:
To propose a referendum (or a petition), you should publish your proposal from a judge. Your proposal should contain the following information:

  1. Area: you should define to which area your proposal is aiming at. It could be your village or city, your region, your country or the whole world. The area will set a geographical limit on who can vote. The subject of your proposal should concern only this area. In case the proposal is successful, it should be applied by the governing authorities of this area within their scope of responsibilities.
  2. Title: the title of your proposal should be short and capture the idea your are proposing, for example "Safer streets in our village"
  3. Description: the description text should provide all the necessary details about your proposal, including the description of the problem and the proposed solution with all the implementation details, including the budget. It could be a text of a regulation, a decision to build a specific infrastructure, etc.
  4. Question: (referendum only) the question asked to the citizen should be short and ask appeal a clear answer, for example, "Do you agree with this proposal to limit the speed of vehicles to 30 km/h in our village?"
  5. Answers: (referendum only) the answers should include all the possible answers to the question, generally, "yes" and "no". Note that a "blank" answer is automatically added.
  6. Website: Optionally, you may want to set-up an official website to promote your proposal and provide more argumentation, possibly host a public debate, etc.
  7. Deadline: the deadline of your proposal sets a time limit at which the vote process will be stopped and the result will be published. It should leave enough time to allow the citizens to get informed about your proposal, possibly organize some debate, make a choice and finally vote. If you set it too short, the main risk is that your proposal will receive a low participation and hence its results won't be meaningful. We recommend a minimum of 3 months from the publication date for the deadline.

Once your proposal is published, you are not done! You will needed to promote it so that a maximum of citizens will vote at it and the results of the refendum will have a significant democratic weight. See next question.
q12: Comment promouvoir mon référendum (ou ma pétition) ?
a12:
Promoting a proposal will draw attention to it and increase the participation rate. Having a large participation to a referendum (or petition) is important as it will make it significant from a democratic point of view. Here are some ideas on how to promote your proposal:

  • Spread the word about it around you.
  • Put up posters in the streets of your city, with the QR code of the proposal or website.
  • Publish newspapers articles.
  • Make a campaign on the social networks.
  • Organize local presentations and debates.

If you do a good job, your proposal will be successful, which means it will receive a large participation of the citizens in the proposal's area.
q13: Quand peut-on considérer qu'un référendum (ou une pétition) est un succès ?
a13:
Short answer: when 25% of the population of the area participated.

The success of a referendum is determined by its participation rate. The participation rate in a specific area is defined by the number of citizens who voted (or signed) compared to the total number of citizen living in the area. It is expressed in percent. Depending on the area, the total number of citizens corresponds roughly to 70-80% of the total population after excluding the children. So, for a village in Switzerland, where the adult population is about 80% of the total population, we can consider that a village of 1000 people has roughly 800 citizens. In Switzerland, the participation level to referendums usually around 30-40%. This means that for a village of 1000 inhabitants, about 280 (e.g., 1000 x 0.8 x 0.35) people usually participate, which represents 28% of the total population. We generally consider that when 25% of the population participates, this means that the whole population was aware of the referendum or petition and had a chance to express themselves about it.
q14: Est-ce que les autorités locales vont appliquer les résultats des référendums (ou pétitions) ?
a14:
Short answer: maybe.

It depends whether or not they respect democracy. Most local authorities or governments claim to be democratic. However, in practice they are not and they will probably either ignore the result of the referendum (or petition) or use a bureaucratic justification to reject it. If that happens, this will likely cause dissatisfaction among the people who expressed themselves and these people will likely increase the pressure on the authorities to enforce their democratic decision. This pressure may take several forms. It could increase risk for the authorities of not being re-elected. But it may also cause demonstrations, riots, uprisings, revolutions. Globally, the pressure will endanger the power of the governing people who don't respect the democratic choice of their citizens.

On the long-term, we should see more and more local authorities and governments formally accepting any democratic choice of their citizens expressed through directdemocracy.
q15: Puis-je avoir plus d'informations techniques sur directdemocracy ?
a15: Sure, you will find our white paper on our GitHub repository.
a16:
There are many ways you can help directdemocracy to spread out to the world:

  • Donate: Any financial contribution will help us, we accept donations here.
  • Communicate: spread the word about directdemocracy around you.
  • Document: review and contribute to our documentation, including our web site. Create your own documentation, video tutorial, etc.
  • Translate: you are welcome to translate directdemocracy in your own language or improve an existing translation. This can be done pretty easily on GitHub directly in the i18n folders of the main web site, app, notary, judge or polling station.
  • Review the code: reviewing our source code, finding bugs, proposing patches and improvements are always welcome.
  • Host a webservice: hosting your own notary, judge, or polling station webservice will help directdemocracy scale up to the world and become more resistant to censorship.
  • Develop an app: everyone is free to develop their own version of the directdemocracy app, as the system is designed to allow several apps to co-exist.
